intro: Androcymbium cuspidatum, commonly known as the narrow-leaved cymbium, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along stream banks. Due to its specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many areas.
